prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [O III] in MACS 0940
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 9 observations of the [O III] 88 micron emission line in the compact configuration

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Ultraviolet spectral features (including the [O III] 1661,1666 Angstrom emission lines) indicate a line width of 150 km/s FWHM for this galaxy. The coarse spectral resolution corresponding to 14 km/s per channel therefore corresponds to ~10 channels per line width which is easily sufficient for our purposes.
We have specified a second continuum baseband in order to override the default local oscillator tuning, which placed one sideband in a low-transmission region of the spectrum. Configuring all basebands to be in high-transmission regions minimized the exposure time needed to reach our requested sensitivity.

Our goal is to detect the [O III] emission line. We do not seek spatially resolved information and so we request the coarsest possible angular resolution in order to avoid extra noise from combining flux from multiple synthesized beams. The angular size of the target is 0.3x1.5 arcseconds measured from HST imaging (Figure 4 of science case) and hence the largest angular scale is 1.5 arcseconds. There is no risk of significant flux loss from resolving the source especially since it is elongated (only 0.3 arcseconds wide).

We have estimated the total [O III] 88 micron line flux based on the observed rest-UV magnitude and spectroscopic redshift of the source (Table 1 of science justification), using the prescription described by Inoue et al (2014). We conservatively assume metallicity ~0.1 times the solar value based on features in the high dispersion rest-UV spectrum (Figure 3 of science justification). We assume no dust extinction and therefore our flux estimate is a conservative lower limit. The UV spectral slope indicates moderate dust extinction although this is degenerate with the age of the stellar population.
We are targeting the most highly magnified image of the lensed galaxy, which subtends 1x3 beams in the compact configuration (0.3x1.5 arcseconds; Figure 4 of the science justification). We estimate a total [O III] flux density of 12.5 mJy for this image within a 150 km/s line width (FWHM measured from the rest-UV spectrum), or average 4.2 mJy per beam. We therefore request a sensitivity of 1.4 mJy/beam for this bandwidth in order to detect [O III] at 3sigma per beam and 5sigma integrated over the source. This is a conservative firm lower limit accounting for uncertainties in the dust extinction and metallicity; we expect a minimum >5sigma detection for all reasonable values allowed by our rest-UV data. While two other images of the lensed galaxy appear nearby (Figure 4), they are at the edge of the primary beam and will not contribute significantly to the detection.
We note that the "peak flux" value entered in the source properties is actually the average flux density within the line FWHM. The true estimated peak flux and corresponding S/N is therefore higher than indicated such that we expect a total S/N > 5.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [O III] in SDSS J1621
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 9 observations of the [O III] 88 micron emission line in the compact configuration

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Ultraviolet spectral features (including the [O III] 1661,1666 Angstrom emission lines) indicate a line width of 150 km/s FWHM for this galaxy. The coarse spectral resolution corresponding to 14 km/s per channel therefore corresponds to ~10 channels per line width which is easily sufficient for our purposes.
We have specified a second continuum baseband in order to override the default local oscillator tuning, which placed one sideband in a low-transmission region of the spectrum. Configuring all basebands to be in high-transmission regions minimized the exposure time needed to reach our requested sensitivity.

Our goal is to detect the [O III] emission line. We do not seek spatially resolved information and so we request the coarsest possible angular resolution in order to avoid extra noise from combining flux from multiple synthesized beams. The angular size of the target is 0.3x2.0 arcseconds measured from HST imaging (Figure 4 of science case) and hence the largest angular scale is 2.0 arcseconds. There is no risk of significant flux loss from resolving the source especially since it is elongated (only 0.3 arcseconds wide).

We have estimated the total [O III] 88 micron line flux based on the observed rest-UV magnitude and spectroscopic redshift of the source (Table 1 of science justification), using the prescription described by Inoue et al (2014). We conservatively assume metallicity ~0.1 times the solar value based on features in the high dispersion rest-UV spectrum (Figure 3 of science justification). We assume no dust extinction and therefore our flux estimate is a conservative lower limit. The UV spectral slope indicates moderate dust extinction although this is degenerate with the age of the stellar population.
We are targeting the most highly magnified image of the lensed galaxy, which subtends 1x4 beams in the compact configuration (0.3x2.0 arcseconds; Figure 4 of the science justification). We estimate a total [O III] flux density of 14 mJy for this image within a 150 km/s line width (FWHM measured from the rest-UV spectrum), or average 3.6 mJy per beam. We therefore request a sensitivity of 1.4 mJy/beam for this bandwidth in order to detect [O III] at 2.6sigma per beam and 5sigma integrated over the source. This is a conservative firm lower limit accounting for uncertainties in the dust extinction and metallicity; we expect a minimum >5sigma detection for all reasonable values allowed by our rest-UV data.
We note that the "peak flux" value entered in the source properties is actually the average flux density within the line FWHM. The true estimated peak flux and corresponding S/N is therefore higher than indicated such that we expect a total S/N > 5.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [O III] in Abell 2390 H3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 9 observations of the [O III] 88 micron emission line in the compact configuration

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We estimate a line width of ~150 km/s FWHM from ultraviolet spectral features seen in Figure 3, although this value is less well measured than our other targets due to lower signal/noise in the nebular emission lines. Nonetheless the features including narrow Lyman alpha emission are well resolved and we expect that the coarse spectral resolution (14 km/s per channel) will provide ~10 channels per line width which is easily sufficient for our purposes.
We have specified a second continuum baseband in order to override the default local oscillator tuning, which placed one sideband in a low-transmission region of the spectrum. Configuring all basebands to be in high-transmission regions minimized the exposure time needed to reach our requested sensitivity.

Our goal is to detect the [O III] emission line. We do not seek spatially resolved information and so we request the coarsest possible angular resolution in order to avoid extra noise from combining flux from multiple synthesized beams. The angular size of the target is 0.3x1.5 arcseconds measured from HST imaging (Figure 4 of science case) and hence the largest angular scale is 1.5 arcseconds. There is no risk of significant flux loss from resolving the source especially since it is elongated (only 0.3 arcseconds wide).

We have estimated the total [O III] 88 micron line flux based on the observed rest-UV magnitude and spectroscopic redshift of the source (Table 1 of science justification), using the prescription described by Inoue et al (2014). We conservatively assume metallicity ~0.1 times the solar value based on features in the high dispersion rest-UV spectrum (Figure 3 of science justification). We assume no dust extinction and therefore our flux estimate is a conservative lower limit. The UV spectral slope indicates moderate dust extinction although this is degenerate with the age of the stellar population.
We are targeting the southern image of the lensed galaxy, which subtends 1x3 beams in the compact configuration (0.3x1.5 arcseconds; Figure 4 of the science justification). We estimate a total [O III] flux density of 13.5 mJy for this image within an estimated 150 km/s line width, or average 4.5 mJy per beam. We therefore request a sensitivity of 1.5 mJy/beam for this bandwidth in order to detect [O III] at 3sigma per beam and 5sigma integrated over the source. This is a conservative firm lower limit accounting for uncertainties in the dust extinction and metallicity; we expect a minimum >5sigma detection for all reasonable values allowed by our rest-UV data. While another image of the lensed galaxy appears nearby (Figure 4), it falls beyond the primary beam FWHM and will not contribute significantly to the observed flux.
We note that the "peak flux" value entered in the source properties is actually the average flux density within the line FWHM. The true estimated peak flux and corresponding S/N is therefore higher than indicated such that we expect a total S/N > 5.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [O III] in Abell 2390 H5
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 9 observations of the [O III] 88 micron emission line in the compact configuration

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Ultraviolet spectral features (including the [O III] 1661,1666 emission lines) indicate a line width of 130 km/s FWHM for this galaxy. The coarse spectral resolution (14 km/s per channel) will provide ~9 channels per line width which is easily sufficient for our purposes.
We have specified a second continuum baseband in order to override the default local oscillator tuning, which placed one sideband in a low-transmission region of the spectrum. Configuring all basebands to be in high-transmission regions minimized the exposure time needed to reach our requested sensitivity.

Our goal is to detect the [O III] emission line. We do not seek spatially resolved information and so we request the coarsest possible angular resolution in order to avoid extra noise from combining flux from multiple synthesized beams. The angular size of the target in HST imaging is 0.5 arcseconds for the single bright knot which comprises the majority of UV flux (Figure 4 of the science case), and hence the largest angular scale is 0.5 arcseconds.

We have estimated the total [O III] 88 micron line flux based on the observed rest-UV magnitude and spectroscopic redshift of the source (Table 1 of science justification), using the prescription described by Inoue et al (2014). We conservatively assume metallicity ~0.1 times the solar value based on features in the high dispersion rest-UV spectrum (Figure 3 of science justification). We assume no dust extinction and therefore our flux estimate is a conservative lower limit. The UV spectral slope indicates moderate dust extinction although this is degenerate with the age of the stellar population.
We are targeting the brighter southern image of the lensed galaxy, which is contained within a single synthesized beam in the compact configuration ('H5b' in Figure 4 of the science justification). We estimate a total [O III] flux density of 8.5 mJy for this image within a 130 km/s line width (FWHM measured from the rest-UV spectrum). We therefore request a sensitivity of 1.7 mJy/beam for this bandwidth in order to detect [O III] at 5sigma significance. This is a conservative firm lower limit accounting for uncertainties in the dust extinction and metallicity; we expect a minimum >5sigma detection for all reasonable values allowed by our rest-UV data. While another image of the lensed galaxy appears nearby (Figure 4), it falls beyond the primary beam FWHM and will not contribute significantly to the observed flux.
We note that the "peak flux" value entered in the source properties is actually the average flux density within the line FWHM. The true estimated peak flux and corresponding S/N is therefore higher than indicated such that we expect a total S/N > 5.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a search for the 88 micron emission line of [O III] in a sample of four well-studied gravitationally lensed galaxies at redshifts z>4. Recent work has demonstrated the line is stronger than [C II] 158 micron in low-metallicity nearby galaxies and is a more direct probe of the star formation rate in H II regions. As a result it has been proposed as the most promising spectroscopic probe of galaxies at z>8 prior to the launch of JWST. As our z>4 lensed galaxies have intrinsic luminosities and metallicities comparable to those expected at such high redshifts, they provide a valuable test of this diagnostic approach prior to embarking on ambitious exposures in the heart of the reionization era.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics, California at Santa Barbara, University of
